solution_line_template: Jennie can cover the {distance}-mile distance in {time_heavy_traffic} hours when there is heavy traffic, so her average speed is {distance}/{time_heavy_traffic} = <<{distance}/{time_heavy_traffic}={speed_heavy_traffic}>>{speed_heavy_traffic}mph

She can cover the same distance in {time_no_traffic} hours when there is no traffic for an average speed of {distance}/{time_no_traffic} = <<{distance}/{time_no_traffic}={speed_no_traffic}>>{speed_no_traffic}mph
The difference in average speed between the two scenarios is ({speed_no_traffic}-{speed_heavy_traffic})mph = <<({speed_no_traffic}-{speed_heavy_traffic})={speed_difference}>>{speed_difference}mph
